thread.title: Why Job Gains Aren't Luring Millennials From Mom & Dad's Basement
thread.title_full: Why Job Gains Aren't Luring Millennials From Mom & Dad's Basement

title: Why Job Gains Aren't Luring Millennials From Mom & Dad's Basement
text:
Why Job Gains Aren't Luring Millennials From Mom & Dad's Basement Written by: Carleton English 08/05/15 - 7:27 AM EDT Tickers in this article: GS 
NEW YORK (TheStreet) -- Even an improving job market isn't enough to get millennials to move out of their childhood homes, says Goldman Sachs . At least not when they're still grappling with high student debt, low starting salaries and increasing rents. 
Unemployment among 18- to 34-year-olds has dropped from a high of nearly 14% in 2010, just two years after the financial crisis, to 8%. That's almost reaching the 7% rate in 2007, but it hasn't enabled the generation born from 1980 to 2000 to match historical patterns in achieving one of the most basic adult milestones -- getting their own places . 
With a population of about 92 million, millennials are the largest generation in U.S. history, outnumbering even baby boomers, so their spending patterns are important for both individual companies and the economy as a whole. More Headlines
